title: SMALL CAP MOVERS: Watchstone agrees last-minute settlement in legal wrangle with Slater & Gordon
text:
A long-running dispute between insurance services firm Watchstone and Anglo-Aussie lawyers Slater & Gordon finally came to an end this week, bookending an acrimonious tit-for-tat exchange between the two companies.

The parties agreed a settlement on Monday just hours before a High Court hearing was due to start regarding a fraud lawsuit filed by Slater in 2017 against Watchstone, then known as Quindell, over its disastrous acquisition of the latter’s professional services unit that ultimately cost it £450million in write-downs.

Slater was seeking £637million in damages, less than the £673million it paid for the business shortly before the UK’s Serious Fraud Office began an investigation into Quindell’s accounting practices.

Insurance services firm Watchstone and Anglo-Aussie lawyers Slater & Gordon agreed a settlement on Monday just hours before a High Court hearing was due to start

Watchstone hit back with a £63million counterclaim in August, alleging that Slater’s corporate finance advisor, Greenhill & Co, had established a ‘back channel’ with its restructuring consultant, PwC, to obtain confidential information during negotiations.

However, the two sides have walked away with far less than intended, with Watchstone receiving £39million and Slater £11million. Neither firm has admitted any wrongdoing.

While the settlement may not be as much as the company was after, Watchstone’s investors seem relieved the matter has been put to rest, as the shares shot up 55 per cent to 166p during the week.

The AIM All-Share was 1.3 per cent higher at 892 in the week, while the FTSE 100 was up 2.2 per cent at 7,306.

On the high street, retailer Shoe Zone found itself on firmer footing after reporting that trading had got no worse following a profit warning in August.

The company, which sells 18million pairs of shoes each year, saw revenues rise by 1 per cent to £161.9million in the 53 weeks to 5 October. The stabilised performance was enough to push the shares up 16 per cent to 131p over the week.

Firestone Diamonds sparkled after a trading update said a power outage that had affected operations at its Liqhobong mine in Lesotho was expected to be resolved by early November. The stock surged 29 per cent to 0.7p in response.

Telecoms manufacturer Filtronic received a good reception from investors, rising 11 per cent to 9p, after reporting that demand was looking up after a ‘challenging year’.

Despite profits in its latest full-year being almost completely wiped out, falling to £100,000 from £2.7million, the company predicted ‘significant organic growth’ in the coming year.

Personnel and talent management specialist Mind Gym also flexed 9 per cent higher to 134p as the firm said full-year revenues would be slightly ahead of expectations after increasing the proportion of incomes derived from its 25 biggest accounts.

In the fallers, gold miner Panthera Resources was mauled after another delay to its legal case before the Rajasthan High Court in India sent the stock tumbling 15 per cent to 7.3p.

Rum, gin and vodka maker Distil suffered a hangover after a slump in half-year revenues

The firm originally filed the claim in September last year against the government of the state following the rejection of a prospecting license application from its joint venture partner, however, since then the process has been hit by several delays, the most recent being due to ‘staff shortages’ at the court.

Rum, gin and vodka maker Distil suffered a hangover after a slump in half-year revenues due to ‘challenges’ in its core markets sent the stock tumbling 20 per cent to 0.7p.

Revenue in the six months to the end of September fell to £824,000 from £1.16 million in the same period of 2018, while gross profit declined 30 per cent to £499,000 from £710,000.

Troubled phone app and game distributor Mobile Streams plunged 32 per cent to 0.2p after telling investors that it had still not managed to find a new nominated advisor, a requirement to trade on the AIM market. If the firm fails to find a replacement before next Tuesday, its shares will be suspended.
